Name: Pattern Recognition - PE
Text: The normative process has two main paths based on inventory availability. If inventory is sufficient, the process goes: Receive, Check, Authorize Payment, Package, Ship, Close. If inventory is insufficient, it's: Receive, Check, Cancel, Close.

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Looking at the event log, each case has a series of activities with timestamps. I'll go through each case one by one.

Name: Validation - PE
Text: Case 1: This follows the correct sequence for sufficient inventory. No issues here.

Name: Validation - NE
Text: Case 2: After Check, it jumps to Package, then Authorize. That's a violation because Authorize should only happen after Check and before Package.

Name: Validation - NE
Text: Case 3: If inventory is insufficient, after Check, it should Cancel, and then Close. In this case, it's Authorizing before Canceling, which is incorrect.

Name: Validation - PE
Text: Case 4: Here, after Check, it Cancel without Authorizing, which is correct if inventory is insufficient. So this seems okay.

Name: Validation - PE
Text: Case 5: This follows the sufficient inventory path: Receive, Check, Authorize, Ship, Close. No issues.

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: To summarize: Case 2 violated the order by Authorizing before Packaging. Case 3 violated by Authorizing before Canceling, which is incorrect when inventory is insufficient. Case 4 followed the correct insufficient inventory path. Case 1 and 5 followed the correct sufficient inventory path.
